Name: Linear Programming
Description: A problem of optimizing a linear objective function subject to linear equality and inequality constraints.
Solvability: Polynomial-time solvable (via Simplex or Interior-Point methods)
Example: Minimizing transportation costs while meeting demand and supply constraints.

Name: Quadratic Programming
Description: A type of mathematical optimization where the objective function is quadratic and constraints are linear.
Solvability: Convex programming; can be solved in polynomial time when the problem is convex.
Example: Portfolio optimization with a risk-return trade-off model.

Name: Nonlinear Programming
Description: Optimization problems where the objective function or some of the constraints are nonlinear.
Solvability: Varies based on the problem's specific properties
Appearances: Optimizing fuel consumption for an aircraft during flight.

Name: Convex Optimization
Description: Optimization problems where the objective is a convex function and the feasible set is a convex set.
Appearances: Robust control design in systems engineering.

Name: Integer Programming
Description: A form of linear programming where some or all decision variables are constrained to be integers.
column8: Scheduling staff shifts at a hospital with full-time and part-time workers.

Name: Mixed-Integer Linear Programming
Description: Linear optimization problems that involve both continuous and integer variables.
Solvability: NP-hard; often requires heuristics or approximation methods for large instances
Example: Supply chain network design involving facility location and transportation routes.

Name: Combinatorial Optimization
Description: Optimization where the solution space is discrete or can be reduced to a finite set of feasible solutions.
Solvability: Often NP-hard; specific problems may have polynomial-time algorithms
Example: Determining the shortest path in a weighted graph (e.g.

Name: Stochastic Programming
Solvability: where some parameters are random variables.
Example: Complexity depends on problem specifics and often requires scenario-based approaches or sampling methods
Appearances: Financial portfolio management considering uncertain market returns.

Name: Dynamic Programming
Description: A method for solving complex problems by breaking them down into simpler subproblems
Solvability: Optimization of sequential decisions with overlapping subproblems (e.g.
Appearances: Determining optimal inventory policy over multiple time periods.

Name: Multi-objective Optimization
Description: Involves optimizing two or more conflicting objectives simultaneously.
Solvability: Typically requires trade-off analysis or Pareto front identification
Example: Airport runway scheduling to minimize delay and fuel consumption.
